content.webTitle: Mansion House speech: Supping with bankers | Editorial

fields.headline: Mansion House speech: Supping with bankers
fields.bodyText: The first thing to say about George Osborne's maiden Mansion House speech last night is that the Conservative chancellor has gone much further in tackling the banks than his Labour predecessor, Alistair Darling, would have done. The second thing to say is that he still does not go far enough – and in the gulf between those two positions lies the feebleness of Westminster's response to the biggest banking crisis since the first world war. First though, credit where it is due. The Tories were always ahead of Labour when it came to reforming the banks (even while David Cameron was all over the shop when Northern Rock and Bradford & Bingley were actually falling over) – and last night's announcements show that they have not lost that impetus in power. Just look at what the new chancellor is promising: a tax on banks, brought in without Labour quavering about Britain going it alone; the transfer of powers from the Financial Services Authority, which was meant to monitor bad behaviour at banks but instead fell asleep – and, the appointment of a new commission to look into reforming the finance industry. Mr Osborne is under no obligation to follow commission recommendations, but still this does not look like the political equivalent of a drop kick into the long grass. The panellists include Martin Wolf of the FT and former regulator Claire Spottiswoode – both of whom are on the record as wanting to split up banks that are too big or unwieldy. What a difference this makes from those dreary Labour-appointed inquiries into the City headed by exactly those bankers who would make sure that they came up with precisely nothing. Full marks, then? Well, no. First, the chancellor's new regime gives too much power with Mervyn King at the Bank of England. Not only has Mr King blotted his copybook in this crisis – being slow to cut interest rates and wittering about moral hazard and other high-table arcana while Northern Rock was mid-collapse – now he faces contradictory pressures. What if Megabank, say, is in meltdown and needs low interest rates but the economy is overheating and requires a big rate rise? The don of Threadneedle Street will be pulled both ways. What is also missing from these proposals is a sense of what banks are for. Either we use them to channel funds into green technology and other parts of the economy that need it – as the New Economics Foundation recommends – or we leave them to stoke up the next credit boom and bust. This is a debate that the prospective Labour leaders need to engage with, too. This once-in-a-lifetime banking crisis should not merely produce sleeker watchdogs – it offers far more and bigger lessons than that.
